about.title: ABOUT ME
about.p1: Hi, I'm Andy! I'm 20 and I'm currently a senior student at Cornell University. I'm majoring in Computer Science with a minor in Game Design. I have been programming for over 6 years and have experience in making games for over 3 years.
about.p2: Since I was a kid, I've always had three big goals on my bucket list: to make a positive impact on my community, to travel and learn about the diverse cultures of our planet, and to live a happy life.
about.p3: While I might not be the best judge of how much impact I've made, I can confidently say that I'm living a happy life, thanks to the incredible people I've met and the perspectives I've gained from traveling the world. It may not seem like much, but I'm deeply grateful for everything I have.
about.p4: When I'm not working on my next project, I love taking time off to be with friends and family. I also enjoy indulging in activities like tennis, skiing, cooking, watching movies, listening to music, and, of course, gaming.

card1.title: Unique Mechanics
card1.text: The game features a unique mechanic where players must use their environment to solve puzzles and escape from the haunted factory. This mechanic encourages players to think creatively and adapt to their surroundings.

card2.title: Immersive Experience
card2.text: The game is designed to provide an immersive experience, with a focus on atmosphere and storytelling. Players will feel the tension and fear as they navigate through the haunted factory.

card3.title: Player Engagement
card3.text: The game is designed to keep players engaged with its challenging puzzles and unique mechanics. Players will need to think critically and adapt to the game's challenges to progress.

game_mech.text1: Players must identify the anonymous shape displayed on the order board and assemble it using available enemies on the field.
game_mech.text2: Colors play an important role. Except for pink pieces, which act as erasers, each color grants different bonus points to the final order score once completed.
game_mech.text3: Players can use erasers to correct misplaced pieces by throwing an eraser at the incorrect component.
